did.unittitle: Memorandum's [sic] of Rubens Peale and the events of his life &c, [ca. 1856]
did.abstract: This is an autobiographical work and mainly discusses his father's museum in Philadelphia and his museum in Baltimore (collecting specimens, gas lighting, selling his collections). There are also anecdotes on prominent people of the time. There are notes in an unknown hand (perhaps Mary Jane Peale).

odd.head: Early American History Note
odd.p: The Reubens Peale Memorandum book is more like an autobiography than a memo book. Peale recounts his life, paying particular attention to the history of his father's museums in Baltimore and Philadelphia. Reuben was particularly involved in the Baltimore museum.

odd.head: Administrative Note
odd.p: This record is superseded by, and included in, B P31. It was marked “internal only” in Dec., 2010 and is being kept in the case that it is needed for future administrative needs.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: The papers of C. W. Peale and his family have been reproduced almost in their entirety in microfiche form (Lillian B. Miller, ed. "Collected papers of Charles Willson Peale and his family." Kraus Microfilm, 1980).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Rubens Peale managed his father Charles Wilson Peale's museum in Philadelphia from 1810 to 1822. At that time, he bought his brother Rembrandt's controlling interest in the Peale Museum in Baltimore, He also opened branches in New York City and in Utica, New York. He eventually sold his collection to P.T. Barnum. In 1840, he settled on a farm in Pottsville, where he farmed and painted still-life.
